articles.headline: Buried Garage to Help Pay for New Park in Brooklyn
articles.snippet: The high-tech 700-car garage will sit beneath the downtown park under a deal negotiated by the city.
articles.abstract: The high-tech 700-car garage will sit beneath the downtown park under a deal negotiated by the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the film “Upside Down,” two worlds exist opposite one another, one looking up and the other down, with the potential for a shared future.

articles.headline: Live From the Oval Office: A Backdrop of History Fades From TV
articles.snippet: Recent presidents have limited their use of the Oval Office address, increasingly opting for other modes of communication as cable and the Web compete for viewers’ attention.
articles.abstract: Recent presidents have limited their use of the Oval Office address, increasingly opting for other modes of communication as cable and the Web compete for viewers’ attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At historic moments in the television age, past American presidents turned to the Oval Office as their stage.

articles.headline: Regulators Seek Stiffer Bank Rules on Capital
articles.snippet: The proposal would increase the financial cushion banks must maintain to protect their assets in a crisis.
articles.abstract: The proposal would increase the financial cushion banks must maintain to protect their assets in a crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Confronted with large and complex banks, financial regulators have spent years drafting rules that are just as complicated.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Hopes for Validation in Goldman Sachs Trader Case
articles.snippet: For Fabrice Tourre, an unfavorable verdict could yield a fine, or a ban from the securities industry. For the S.E.C., the trial is a defining moment that follows one courtroom disappointment after another.
articles.abstract: For Fabrice Tourre, an unfavorable verdict could yield a fine, or a ban from the securities industry. For the S.E.C., the trial is a defining moment that follows one courtroom disappointment after another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, in the shadow of the financial crisis, some of the biggest banks on Wall Street slipped into the government’s cross hairs.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Fork in the Road for Barnes & Noble
articles.snippet: The nation’s only major bookstore chain has no clear path forward, reviving fears among publishers, authors and agents about its future.
articles.abstract: The nation’s only major bookstore chain has no clear path forward, reviving fears among publishers, authors and agents about its future.
articles.lead_paragraph: William Lynch was brimming with the enthusiasm of a start-up entrepreneur. It was January 2012, and Mr. Lynch, Barnes & Noble’s chief executive, was showing off the company’s shiny Palo Alto, Calif., offices, a 300-person outpost that was the center of its e-reader operations.

articles.headline: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
articles.snippet: Restaurant owners like Eric King have been highly critical of the employer health insurance mandate, and he said the rule’s delay “gives us another year to plan.”
articles.abstract: Restaurant owners like Eric King have been highly critical of the employer health insurance mandate, and he said the rule’s delay “gives us another year to plan.”
articles.lead_paragraph: ELLICOTT CITY, Md. — Eric King has worked diligently to keep his family’s 35-year-old seafood restaurant here viable, most recently by expanding the menu beyond its well-loved crab cakes and other traditional dishes to draw a younger, freer-spending crowd.

articles.headline: Currency Controls in Cyprus Increase Worry About Euro System
articles.snippet: Restrictions on the flow of capital have given some Cypriots the feeling that not all euros are created equal, raising a crucial question: Is the euro zone already starting to break up?
articles.abstract: Restrictions on the flow of capital have given some Cypriots the feeling that not all euros are created equal, raising a crucial question: Is the euro zone already starting to break up?
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — On a visit to Athens this year, Marios Loucaides, a Cypriot businessman, saw an apartment he liked in the heart of the Greek capital and decided to buy it. He told the owner he would seal the deal with a bank transfer — the price was 170,000 euros, about $220,000 — once he got back to Cyprus.

articles.headline: Egypt Is Arena for Influence of Arab Rivals
articles.snippet: Two of the Persian Gulf’s richest monarchies pledged $8 billion in cash and loans to Egypt, aiming to shore up a shaky government and to compete for influence with each other and with their Islamist rivals.
articles.abstract: Two of the Persian Gulf’s richest monarchies pledged $8 billion in cash and loans to Egypt, aiming to shore up a shaky government and to compete for influence with each other and with their Islamist rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of the Persian Gulf’s richest monarchies pledged $8 billion in cash and loans to Egypt on Tuesday, a decision that was aimed not only at shoring up a shaky transitional government, but also at undermining their Islamist rivals and strengthening their allies across a newly turbulent Middle East.

articles.headline: U.S. Vows to Battle Abusive Debt Collectors
articles.snippet: Federal regulators are cracking down on some of the nation’s biggest banks and other lenders, accusing them of aggressive practices like hounding debtors with repeated phone calls.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators are cracking down on some of the nation’s biggest banks and other lenders, accusing them of aggressive practices like hounding debtors with repeated phone calls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are cracking down on questionable debt collection practices by some of the nation’s biggest lenders.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: Fallout From Apple’s Loss on E-Books
articles.snippet: A judge in federal court Wednesday held that the company had violated antitrust law in helping set the retail price of electronic books, and said a trial for damages would follow.
articles.abstract: A judge in federal court Wednesday held that the company had violated antitrust law in helping set the retail price of electronic books, and said a trial for damages would follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Apple, the words of Steven P. Jobs were often used to win negotiations. But after his death, they have proved damaging.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: U.S. Retailers Offer Plan for Safety at Factories
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart, Gap, Target, Kohl’s, Macy’s and a dozen other retailers are unveiling their alternative to a European-led plan to improve safety at apparel factories in Bangladesh.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart, Gap, Target, Kohl’s, Macy’s and a dozen other retailers are unveiling their alternative to a European-led plan to improve safety at apparel factories in Bangladesh.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of 17 major North American retailers, including Wal-Mart, Gap, Target and Macy’s, announced a plan on Wednesday to improve factory safety in Bangladesh, drawing immediate criticism from labor groups who complained that it was less stringent than an accord reached among European companies.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Law Spoils Tobacco’s Taste, Australians Say
articles.snippet: Sales figures are not available to help determine the effectiveness of an Australian law requiring graphic images on cigarette packages. But some smokers swear there has been a change in the tobacco.
articles.abstract: Sales figures are not available to help determine the effectiveness of an Australian law requiring graphic images on cigarette packages. But some smokers swear there has been a change in the tobacco.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — More than seven months have passed since Australia imposed one of the world’s toughest laws for tobacco warning labels, swapping iconic packaging for graphic images of mouth ulcers, cancerous lungs and gangrenous limbs.
